含义 (meaning): The character '气' primarily means 'air', 'gas', 'breath', or 'vital energy'. In traditional Chinese philosophy and medicine, it often refers to 'Qi', the vital life force that flows through all living beings.
字形 (character structure): The character '气' is composed of the radical '气' (itself) and is a simplified form. It originally depicted steam or vapor rising from a pot, symbolizing air or breath.
读音 (pronunciation): The character '气' is pronounced as 'qì' in Mandarin Chinese.
字源 (etymology): The character '气' evolved from ancient pictographs representing steam or vapor. It was used to denote air, breath, and later, the concept of vital energy in Chinese philosophy.
成语 (idioms): 气势磅礴 (qìshì pángbó - majestic and powerful)
气壮山河 (qì zhuàng shānhé - full of power and grandeur)
气宇轩昂 (qìyǔ xuānáng - dignified and imposing)
例句 (example sentences): 今天的天气真好！(Jīntiān de tiānqì zhēn hǎo! - The weather is really nice today!)
他生气地离开了房间。(Tā shēngqì de líkāile fángjiān. - He left the room angrily.)
短故事 (short stories): In ancient China, a wise man named Laozi once said, 'The Tao gives birth to Qi, and Qi gives birth to all things.' This reflects the belief that Qi is the fundamental energy that sustains life and the universe.

A famous story from Chinese medicine tells of a doctor who could diagnose illnesses by observing the flow of Qi in a patient's body. He would then prescribe herbs and acupuncture to restore the balance of Qi.
诗词 (poetry): 《静夜思》 - 李白 (Jìng Yè Sī - Li Bai): '床前明月光，疑是地上霜。举头望明月，低头思故乡。' (The moonlight before my bed, I suspect it's frost on the ground. I raise my head to gaze at the moon, then lower it, thinking of home.)

《登鹳雀楼》 - 王之涣 (Dēng Guàn Què Lóu - Wang Zhihuan): '白日依山尽，黄河入海流。欲穷千里目，更上一层楼。' (The sun sets behind the mountains, the Yellow River flows into the sea. To see a thousand miles further, climb one more floor of the tower.)
